title: 115_s2981
content: The "Opioid Overdose Reduction Act of 2018" aims to protect individuals who overdose on opioids by providing immunity from civil liability for those administering overdose drugs in emergencies. The Act defines key terms such as "health care professional" as a licensed prescriber, "opioid overdose drug" as a drug that reverses opioid overdose effects, and "opioid overdose program" as a program that provides drugs and education to prevent overdoses. The Act defines key terms related to opioid overdose, including "health care professional," "opioid overdose drug," and "opioid overdose program." It pertains to assisting individuals at risk of opioid overdose. SEC. 4. PREEMPTION AND ELECTION OF STATE NONAPPLICABILITY. This Act preempts State laws inconsistent with it, except for laws providing extra liability protection for opioid overdose drug administration. State can choose not to apply certain sections if all parties are State citizens and State enacts specific legislation. The Act allows States to exempt civil actions from certain sections by enacting specific legislation. SEC. 5. LIMITATION ON CIVIL LIABILITY FOR HEALTH CARE PROFESSIONALS PROVIDING OPIOID OVERDOSE DRUGS. Health care professionals prescribing or providing opioid overdose drugs to individuals at risk of overdose are not liable for harm if the individual has been educated on overdose prevention. Individuals educated on administering opioid overdose drugs must be trained on when and how to administer the drug, as well as the necessary steps to take afterward. Health care professionals are not liable for harm caused by gross negligence or reckless misconduct. Individuals working for or volunteering at a state or local agency opioid overdose program are not liable for harm caused by the emergency administration of an opioid overdose drug by another individual, unless the harm was due to gross negligence or reckless misconduct. SEC. 7. LIMITATION ON CIVIL LIABILITY FOR INDIVIDUALS WHO ADMINISTER OPIOID OVERDOSE DRUGS. SEC. 7. LIMITATION ON CIVIL LIABILITY FOR INDIVIDUALS WHO ADMINISTER OPIOID OVERDOSE DRUGS. Notwithstanding any other provision of law, individuals are not liable for harm caused by administering an opioid overdose drug to someone who appears to have suffered an overdose, as long as the drug was obtained from a healthcare professional or program, or with a prescription, and the individual administering the drug was properly educated. Individuals are not liable for harm caused by administering an opioid overdose drug if obtained from a healthcare professional or program, and if the individual was properly educated, except in cases of gross negligence or reckless misconduct.
